awd_titl_txt: PIPP Phase I: Computational Foundations for Bio-social Modeling of Unseen Pandemics
awd_abstract_narration:
Pandemics unfold in a social, behavioral, and decision-making context that alters the geospatial patterns of spread, depending on an existing underlying landscape of risk and adaptive behavior. Layering socioeconomic factors into traditional predictive modeling frameworks is not sufficient to understand this complexity, nor does it account for the dynamics and vicissitudes of human behavior and free-will. Unexpected human behaviors play a major role, as well as broader factors such as vaccine availability, seasonal effects from human contact patterns, viral environmental persistence, and federal and state-level policy changes around masking and business closures. Enumerating a finite list of factors that should form the basis of a predictive model itself seems like a grand challenge. This project will advance modeling as a continuous, iterative, and dynamic component of pandemic response, where incremental predictions are far more robust, and approaches that innately allow for complexity, adaptation, and surprise can be expected to be operationally useful.

Pandemic prevention for unseen pandemics requires several interconnected efforts across immunology, mechanistic modeling, data-driven modeling, and understanding sociopolitical contexts of decision making. Technical aspects of the project include machine learning based tools for predicting immune response from pathogen mutations, switching dynamical systems based models of time-series for fast adaptation, adaptive population sampling techniques, and model predictive control methods for designing behavioral interventions. The project will develop integrative protocols and frameworks that a) leverage techniques for using binding patterns of pathogens for never-before-seen viruses and advances in wastewater-based epidemiology, b) understand the variation in performance of predictive models over geospatial scales using regularizing models, c) design effective interventions under resource constraints, and d) understand their impact on policy making. 

This award is supported by the cross-directorate Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention Phase I (PIPP) program, which is jointly funded by the Directorates for Biological Sciences (BIO), Computer Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) and Engineering (ENG).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this PIPP Phase 1 planning project, our goal was to gather experts from multiple areas of expertise related to pandemic decision making and preparedness, to develop an integrative multidisciplinary vision for future pandemic responses. We gathered disciplinary experts across areas such as virology, public health, data science, and social sciences. We are grateful for the funding which has enabled us to advance our interdisciplinary engagement across diverse areas of inquiry within our team. 

We made particular advances in modeling population scale mobility, with graphical  representations of population dynamics and change detection techniques that leverage the graph structure. We have made multiple advances in the use of advanced machine learning techniques in the analysis of wearable devices for health and wellness. These have resulted in multiple publications. We have supported several graduate students on various aspects of the project that advanced several crosscutting focus areas of our research tasks. Different training opportunities have included training in data science, machine learning, gene sequencing, optimization, human subjects training, interviews, and manuscript preparation for scientific dissemination.

As part of the requirement of the Phase 1 award, we completed a comprehensive workshop on October 13th 2023 on the ASU campus, convening our full team (21 researchers, 1 project coordinator, and 20 students), with the goal of synthesizing and developing an integrative vision. The effort was also considered to be of significant institutional importance, as a comprehensive public health initiative was being developed by ASU to launch an Arizona Health Observatory. There were many avenues for shared resources, collaboration, and knowledge transfer that were identified, which continue to inform the development of the ASU Health enterprise.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Pavan K Turaga
